content:
üìã Quick Reference Everything on this page is what I actually use. Links go to Amazon ‚Äî using them supports this site at no extra cost to you.
The Essentials #These are the must-haves. You can’t reconstitute or inject without them.
1. Bacteriostatic Water (BAC Water) #What it is: Sterile water with 0.9% benzyl alcohol that prevents bacterial growth. This is what you mix with the peptide powder.
Don’t use: Regular sterile water (no preservative = bacteria risk), saline, or tap water.
‚úì Recommended Bacteriostatic Water 30ml ‚Äî One vial lasts multiple reconstitutions
Buy on Amazon ‚Üí
How much to buy: 1-2 vials to start. Each 30ml vial can reconstitute 10+ peptide vials depending on your concentration.
2. Insulin Syringes #What you need: U-100 insulin syringes, 1ml (100 units), with attached needles.
Needle size: 29-31 gauge, ¬Ω inch length. Smaller gauge = thinner needle = less pain.
‚úì Recommended Easy Touch 31G 1ml Insulin Syringes (100 count)
Buy on Amazon ‚Üí
How many: Box of 100 lasts months if you’re injecting weekly.
3. Alcohol Prep Pads #What they’re for: Sterilizing the vial top and your injection site.
‚úì Recommended Alcohol Prep Pads (200 count) ‚Äî Generic is fine
Buy on Amazon ‚Üí
4. Sharps Container #Required for safety. Don’t throw used syringes in the trash.
‚úì Recommended 1 Quart Sharps Container ‚Äî Small enough for home use, lasts a long time
Buy on Amazon ‚Üí
Disposal: When full, check your local pharmacy ‚Äî many accept sharps containers for free disposal.
Optional But Helpful # üßä Small Cooler Bag For traveling with reconstituted peptides. Keep them cold but not frozen.
Buy on Amazon ‚Üí üè∑Ô∏è Labels Mark your vials with reconstitution date and concentration.
Buy on Amazon ‚Üí ‚öñÔ∏è Kitchen Scale For hitting your protein goals (100+ grams daily).
Buy on Amazon ‚Üí Quick Copy-Paste Shopping List #‚ñ° Bacteriostatic water 30ml (1-2 vials) ‚ñ° Insulin syringes 31G 1ml (box of 100) ‚ñ° Alcohol prep pads (200 count) ‚ñ° Sharps container (1 quart) ‚ñ° Small cooler bag (optional, for travel) What About the Peptides? #This page covers supplies only. For where to actually get semaglutide or tirzepatide:
Compare All Options Brand vs compounded vs research Research Peptide Sources Vendors I've actually used Shop Royal Peptides My go-to supplier Ready to Mix? # Step-by-Step Reconstitution Guide ‚Üí How to mix your peptides safely Affiliate Disclosure: Links on this page go to Amazon. If you buy through them, I earn a small commission at no extra cost to you. Full disclosure ‚Üí

content:
‚ö†Ô∏è Important Disclaimer Research peptides are sold for research purposes only and are not FDA-approved for human use. This page shares my personal experience. You assume all responsibility for your own decisions. Full disclaimer ‚Üí
What I Look For in a Vendor #After trying several vendors, here’s what matters:
üß™ Third-Party Testing COA (Certificate of Analysis) from independent lab. Shows purity %.
üá∫üá∏ US-Based Faster shipping, less customs risk, easier returns.
üì¶ Cold Shipping Peptides degrade in heat. Good vendors ship with ice packs.
üí¨ Responsive Support Issues happen. You want a company that answers.
Red Flags to Avoid # üö© Don’t buy from vendors who:
Won’t provide COA/testing results Ship from overseas with no tracking Have no customer service contact Offer prices that seem too good to be true ($20 for 10mg = suspicious) Have no online reputation or reviews Only accept crypto with no other payment options Where I Buy #After trying a few vendors, this is who I use and recommend:
üëë Royal Peptides US-based ‚Ä¢ Third-party tested ‚Ä¢ Fast shipping What they have:
Semaglutide (5mg, 10mg vials) Tirzepatide (5mg, 10mg, 15mg vials) BPC-157 (healing/recovery peptide) Other research peptides Why I use them:
COA available for every batch Ships from US with cold packs Consistent quality across multiple orders Good customer service when I had questions Product Size Price Semaglutide 5mg ~$55-65 Semaglutide 10mg ~$85-95 Tirzepatide 10mg ~$90-100 Tirzepatide 15mg ~$110-120 *Prices may vary. Check site for current pricing.
Visit Royal Peptides ‚Üí
Cost Comparison: Research vs Other Options # Option Monthly Cost Prescription? Notes LillyDirect (Zepbound) $299-449 Yes FDA-approved, brand name Telehealth compounded $150-300 Yes Prescription compounded Research peptides $50-150 No DIY, no medical oversight Research peptides are the cheapest option but require you to:
Reconstitute (mix) the peptides yourself Calculate your own doses Take responsibility for your own decisions How Much Do You Need? #For semaglutide:
Maintenance dose (already lost weight): 0.25-0.5mg/week Active weight loss: 0.5-2.4mg/week A 10mg vial at maintenance dose lasts 20-40 weeks For tirzepatide:
Maintenance dose: 2.5-5mg/week Active weight loss: 5-15mg/week A 15mg vial at active dose lasts 1-3 weeks ‚Üí Use the dosing calculator to figure out exactly what you need.
My Typical Order #For maintenance (I’ve already lost the weight):
Every 2-3 months:
1x Semaglutide 10mg vial (~$85-95) Bacteriostatic water if running low Total: ~$30-50/month for maintenance
Compare that to $449/month for Zepbound at maintenance doses. The savings add up.
Frequently Asked Questions # Is it legal to buy research peptides?
Research peptides are legal to purchase in the US for research purposes. They’re not FDA-approved for human use. The legal gray area is in how you use them.
How do I know the peptides are real?
Look for third-party COA (Certificate of Analysis) showing purity. Reputable vendors like Royal Peptides provide these for every batch.
Can I just inject the powder?
No. Peptides come as lyophilized (freeze-dried) powder. You must reconstitute them with bacteriostatic water first.
How should I store them?
Unreconstituted (powder): Room temperature is fine, refrigerator is better Reconstituted (mixed): Must be refrigerated, use within 4-6 weeks What if I’m not comfortable with DIY?
Then research peptides aren’t for you ‚Äî and that’s okay. Consider telehealth compounded options instead. You get a prescription and pre-mixed medication.

content:
Quick Answer Same Drug? Key Differences Cost Effectiveness Which to Choose ‚ö° The Short Answer Same active ingredient, different everything else. Compounded semaglutide and Wegovy both contain semaglutide. The difference is who makes it, how it's regulated, and what it costs. Wegovy is FDA-approved and made by Novo Nordisk. Compounded is made by compounding pharmacies during drug shortages, at a fraction of the price.
If you’re researching semaglutide, you’ve probably noticed a huge price gap between “compounded semaglutide” ($100-250/month) and “Wegovy” ($1,000+/month). What’s the difference? Is compounded safe? Does it work the same?
Let me break it down.
Are They the Same Drug? Yes and no.
The Active Ingredient Both contain semaglutide ‚Äî the GLP-1 receptor agonist that reduces appetite, slows gastric emptying, and helps with weight loss. Same molecule.
But the products themselves are different:
Wegovy Compounded Semaglutide Manufacturer Novo Nordisk (pharma giant) Compounding pharmacies FDA Approved Yes No (but FDA-regulated during shortages) Format Pre-filled auto-injector pen Vials (you draw with syringe) Quality Control Pharma-grade, batch-tested Varies by pharmacy Price $1,000+/month (list) $100-250/month Think of it like brand-name Tylenol vs. generic acetaminophen. Same active ingredient, different manufacturers, different packaging, different prices.
Key Differences Explained 1. Who Makes It # üíä Wegovy Made by Novo Nordisk, the Danish pharmaceutical company. Manufactured in massive, FDA-inspected facilities with rigorous quality control. Every batch is tested for purity, potency, and sterility.
üè• Compounded Made by compounding pharmacies ‚Äî specialized pharmacies that create customized medications. Quality varies. Legit 503B pharmacies are FDA-registered and inspected. Sketchy ones... aren't.
2. How It’s Regulated #Wegovy: Full FDA approval. Went through clinical trials, demonstrated safety and efficacy, and is continuously monitored.
Compounded semaglutide: Exists in a gray area. The FDA allows compounding of drugs on the “shortage list.” Semaglutide has been on that list due to high demand. Compounding pharmacies can legally make it, but the final product isn’t FDA-approved.
‚ö†Ô∏è The Shortage List Matters Compounding pharmacies can only legally make semaglutide because it's on the FDA shortage list. If/when Novo Nordisk catches up with demand, semaglutide could come off the list ‚Äî and compounded versions would become legally questionable.
This is what happened with tirzepatide (Zepbound/Mounjaro) in late 2024 ‚Äî it came off the shortage list, and compounding largely stopped.
3. Format and Delivery #Wegovy: Pre-filled auto-injector pens. Click a button, it injects. No measuring, no syringes, no math.
Compounded: Typically comes in vials. You’ll need to:
Draw the correct amount with a syringe Possibly reconstitute (mix powder with water) depending on the formulation Calculate your dose Some telehealth platforms send pre-mixed, pre-measured syringes. Others send vials. Ask before you sign up.
4. Consistency #Wegovy: Every pen is identical. Precise dosing, consistent formulation.
Compounded: Quality depends on the pharmacy. Good 503B pharmacies produce consistent, high-quality products. Bad ones… don’t.
‚úì Signs of a Legit Compounding Pharmacy 503B registration with FDA State board of pharmacy license Third-party testing certificates available Transparent about their processes Named on the telehealth platform's website üö© Red Flags Won't tell you which pharmacy compounds it Prices way below market ($50/month compounded = suspicious) No verifiable pharmacy information Ships from overseas Cost Comparison This is the big one. The price difference is staggering.
Option Monthly Cost Annual Cost Wegovy (list price) $1,000-1,350 $12,000-16,000 Wegovy (with savings card) ~$500-900 $6,000-11,000 Wegovy (with good insurance) $0-150 $0-1,800 Compounded (telehealth) $100-250 $1,200-3,000 Research peptides (DIY) $50-100 $600-1,200 Why the huge difference?
Novo Nordisk spent billions on R&D, clinical trials, and FDA approval. They also have massive marketing budgets and shareholder expectations. Compounding pharmacies skip all of that ‚Äî they just make the molecule.
Does Compounded Work as Well? For most people, yes.
The active ingredient is the same. If the compounding pharmacy is legitimate and produces quality semaglutide, it should work identically to Wegovy.
What the Science Says No large clinical trials compare compounded semaglutide to Wegovy directly. But the mechanism is identical ‚Äî same molecule binding to the same receptors. Anecdotally, thousands of people report similar results with compounded versions.
Potential Differences #Absorption: Some people report slightly different responses when switching between brand and compounded. This could be due to:
Different formulations (salt form, inactive ingredients) Inconsistent compounding Placebo effect Normal variation in how batches affect you Consistency: Wegovy is the same every time. Compounded may vary slightly between batches or pharmacies.
My Take #I started on brand-name Ozempic (same as Wegovy but for diabetes). When I switched to other options later, the effects were comparable. The medication worked.
Safety Considerations ‚úì Wegovy Safety FDA-approved after clinical trials Pharmaceutical-grade manufacturing Consistent quality control Known safety profile Adverse event reporting system ‚ö†Ô∏è Compounded Safety Quality depends on pharmacy 503B pharmacies are FDA-registered Some pharmacies cut corners Less standardized than pharma Do your research on the pharmacy The Risks of Bad Compounding #When compounding goes wrong, it can be serious:
Contamination ‚Äî Bacteria, particles, or other contaminants Wrong concentration ‚Äî Too much or too little active ingredient Stability issues ‚Äî Medication degrades faster than expected Incorrect formulation ‚Äî Using the wrong salt form or additives This is why pharmacy choice matters. Reputable telehealth platforms use legitimate 503B pharmacies. Sketchy operations might not.
‚Üí Compare telehealth platforms
Which Should You Choose? Decision Framework Choose Wegovy if:
Insurance covers it (or most of it) You want FDA-approved, pharmaceutical-grade medication You prefer pre-filled pens (no measuring) Budget isn't a major constraint You're risk-averse about compounding Choose Compounded if:
Insurance doesn't cover Wegovy Cost is a significant factor ($100-250 vs $1,000+) You're comfortable with a reputable compounding pharmacy You want a prescription but can't afford brand You're okay with vials and syringes The Honest Reality #Most people choosing compounded semaglutide are doing so because of cost. If insurance covered Wegovy at $25/month, few would choose compounded instead.
There’s no shame in that. The medication works. Reputable compounding pharmacies produce quality products. Just do your research on the platform and pharmacy.
How to Get Each Option Getting Wegovy # Talk to your doctor about a Wegovy prescription Check insurance coverage ‚Äî call your pharmacy benefit number Apply for savings card at wegovy.com (if commercially insured) Fill at pharmacy ‚Äî may need prior authorization Alternative: Some telehealth platforms (like Ro) can prescribe brand Wegovy and help you fill through normal pharmacy channels.
Getting Compounded Semaglutide # Choose a telehealth platform ‚Äî Mochi Health, Hers, Henry Meds, etc. Complete health questionnaire and provider consultation Get prescribed ‚Äî prescription included in the service Medication ships to you ‚Äî pre-mixed or in vials depending on platform ‚Üí Compare telehealth platforms
Comparison Summary # Factor Wegovy Compounded Semaglutide Active Ingredient Semaglutide Semaglutide Manufacturer Novo Nordisk Compounding pharmacies FDA Approved Yes No Cost (no insurance) $1,000+/mo $100-250/mo Format Pre-filled pens Vials or pre-filled syringes Quality Control Pharmaceutical-grade Varies by pharmacy Convenience Click and inject May need to measure Availability May have shortages Generally available Insurance Sometimes covered Rarely covered Frequently Asked Questions #Is compounded semaglutide legal? Yes, when produced by a licensed compounding pharmacy during an FDA-recognized shortage. The legality depends on the shortage status.
Will compounded semaglutide show up differently on tests? No. It’s the same molecule. Any testing would show semaglutide.
Can I switch from Wegovy to compounded (or vice versa)? Yes. Same active ingredient. You may notice slight differences in how it feels, but the mechanism is identical.
Why doesn’t insurance cover compounded? Insurance typically only covers FDA-approved medications. Compounded drugs aren’t FDA-approved (even if the ingredient is the same).
Is Ozempic the same as Wegovy? Same active ingredient (semaglutide), different dosing and FDA approval. Ozempic is approved for diabetes; Wegovy is approved for weight loss. Higher max dose with Wegovy.
What happens if semaglutide comes off the shortage list? Compounding would become legally questionable. Telehealth platforms would likely stop offering it or pivot to other solutions.
The Bottom Line # Same drug, different packaging, wildly different prices.
Wegovy is the gold standard ‚Äî FDA-approved, consistent, convenient. But at $1,000+/month without insurance, it's out of reach for many people.
Compounded semaglutide from a reputable source is a legitimate alternative. Do your research on the telehealth platform and pharmacy, and you can get effective medication at a fraction of the cost.
Related Reading # Best Telehealth Platforms Compare compounded options All GLP-1 Options Ranked Brand vs compounded vs research My Story How I navigated all of this Questions? contact@glp1afterdenial.com
Affiliate Disclosure: Some links earn a small commission at no extra cost to you.

content:
Check Coverage Prior Authorization Qualifying Conditions If Denied Alternatives ‚ö° The Reality Check Most insurance plans don't cover Zepbound for weight loss. I tried to get it covered ‚Äî my insurance excluded weight loss medications entirely, and finding doctors willing to write prior authorizations was a hassle. I ended up going self-pay. This guide covers everything I learned, including what to do if you hit the same wall.
Getting Zepbound (tirzepatide) covered by insurance is possible, but it’s often an uphill battle. Here’s the honest breakdown of what works, what doesn’t, and when it makes sense to just pay out of pocket.
Step 1: Check Your Actual Coverage Before anything else, find out what your plan actually covers. Many people waste weeks on prior authorizations only to discover their plan explicitly excludes weight loss medications.
How to Check # 1 Call the number on your insurance card and ask: "Does my plan cover Zepbound for weight loss?" Get the answer in writing if possible. 2 Ask specifically about exclusions. Some plans exclude ALL weight loss medications. If that's the case, prior authorization won't help. 3 Check your formulary. This is the list of covered drugs. Zepbound may be Tier 3-5 (expensive) or not listed at all. 4 Ask about step therapy. Some plans require you to try (and fail) other medications first. What You’ll Likely Hear # ‚ùå Bad News "Weight loss medications are excluded" "Zepbound is not on our formulary" "Only covered for Type 2 diabetes" ‚úì Good News "Covered with prior authorization" "Covered for qualifying conditions" "On formulary, Tier 3" If your plan excludes weight loss meds entirely: Skip to alternatives. No amount of prior auth paperwork will help.
Step 2: The Prior Authorization Process If your plan does cover Zepbound with prior authorization, here’s what that process looks like.
What Is Prior Authorization? #Prior authorization (PA) means your doctor has to prove to the insurance company that you medically need Zepbound before they’ll cover it. It’s paperwork, and it’s annoying.
What Your Doctor Needs to Submit # Typical PA Requirements BMI documentation ‚Äî Usually 30+ (or 27+ with comorbidities) Documented weight loss attempts ‚Äî Diet, exercise, sometimes other medications Comorbid conditions ‚Äî Sleep apnea, hypertension, prediabetes, PCOS, etc. Letter of medical necessity ‚Äî Your doctor explains why you need this specific medication The Catch: Finding a Doctor Who Will Do It #This was my biggest frustration. Many doctors:
Don’t want to deal with PA paperwork (it’s time-consuming and often unpaid) Aren’t familiar with GLP-1s for weight loss Work in practices that don’t prioritize weight management Options:
Ask your PCP directly if they’ll submit a prior auth Find an obesity medicine specialist (they do this all the time) Use a telehealth platform that handles PA (like Ro or Found) Conditions That Improve Your Chances Insurance companies are more likely to approve Zepbound if you have documented comorbidities. These conditions can strengthen your case:
üò¥ Sleep Apnea FDA-approved indication ‚ù§Ô∏è Cardiovascular Disease Strong medical necessity ü©∏ Prediabetes Prevention angle ü´Ä Hypertension Common comorbidity üî¨ PCOS Metabolic connection ü´Å NAFLD Liver disease connection Pro tip: If you suspect you have sleep apnea but haven’t been diagnosed, get a sleep study. Zepbound is specifically FDA-approved for obstructive sleep apnea, which can make approval easier.
What to Do If You're Denied Got a denial letter? You have options.
1. Appeal the Decision #You have the right to appeal. The process:
1 Request the specific reason for denial in writing 2 Have your doctor write a detailed appeal letter addressing their concerns 3 Include additional documentation (lab results, specialist letters, weight history) 4 Submit within the deadline (usually 60-180 days) Reality check: Appeals take time and energy. Success rates vary wildly. If your plan has a blanket exclusion, appeals rarely work.
2. Ask About Mounjaro Instead #Mounjaro is the same medication (tirzepatide) but approved for Type 2 diabetes instead of weight loss. If you have prediabetes or diabetes, your doctor might be able to prescribe Mounjaro instead ‚Äî and some insurance plans cover it more readily.
3. Skip the Fight, Go Self-Pay #This is what I did. After weeks of trying to figure out the insurance maze, I realized:
My plan excluded weight loss meds (no amount of PA would help) Finding doctors to write prior auths was a hassle The mental energy wasn’t worth it I got a prescription for Zepbound and went straight to self-pay through LillyDirect.
Self-Pay Alternatives If insurance isn’t happening, here are your realistic options:
Option 1: LillyDirect (Brand Zepbound) # Monthly Cost $299-449 What You Get Pharmaceutical-grade Zepbound Lilly’s direct-to-patient program offers Zepbound at lower prices than pharmacy list price:
Dose Price 2.5mg (starter) $299/mo 5mg $399/mo 7.5mg - 15mg $449/mo Best for: People who want the real, FDA-approved medication. HSA/FSA eligible.
How to access: Get a prescription from your doctor (or telehealth), then use lillydirect.lilly.com
‚Üí Full comparison of your options
Option 2: Telehealth Compounded Semaglutide # Monthly Cost $100-250 What You Get Compounded semaglutide + prescription Can’t afford brand? Telehealth platforms offer compounded semaglutide (same ingredient as Ozempic/Wegovy) at lower prices.
Note: Compounded tirzepatide (Zepbound’s ingredient) is largely unavailable as of late 2024 because it’s off the FDA shortage list.
‚Üí Compare telehealth platforms
Option 3: Research Peptides # Monthly Cost $50-150 What You Get DIY tirzepatide or semaglutide The cheapest option, but requires mixing your own medication. Tirzepatide IS available this way (unlike compounded).
Best for: Experienced users on tight budgets. I use this for maintenance after reaching my goal weight.
‚ö†Ô∏è Not for beginners. If you've never been on GLP-1 medications, start with brand or telehealth so you have medical oversight while learning how your body responds. ‚Üí Reconstitution guide ¬∑ ‚Üí Dosing calculator
The Bottom Line # Worth trying insurance if:
Your plan covers weight loss medications You have documented comorbidities (especially sleep apnea) You have a doctor willing to fight for prior auth You have time and patience for the process Skip straight to self-pay if:
Your plan explicitly excludes weight loss meds You’ve already been denied and don’t want to appeal You want medication now, not in 6-8 weeks The hassle isn’t worth your mental energy I went the self-pay route with Zepbound through LillyDirect, then switched to research peptides for maintenance. Not the cheapest path, but it worked for me.
‚Üí Read my full story
FAQ #Q: Can my doctor prescribe Mounjaro for weight loss? Technically yes (off-label), but insurance likely won’t cover it that way. Mounjaro is only FDA-approved for Type 2 diabetes.
Q: Is LillyDirect legitimate? Yes ‚Äî it’s run by Eli Lilly, the company that makes Zepbound. It’s their official patient access program.
Q: Can I use my HSA/FSA for Zepbound? Yes, Zepbound purchased through LillyDirect is HSA/FSA eligible with a valid prescription.
Q: What if I get approved but can’t afford the copay? Look into the Zepbound Savings Card. It can reduce costs, but there are restrictions (doesn’t work with Medicare/Medicaid).
Q: How long does prior authorization take? Usually 1-2 weeks, but it can stretch to 4-6 weeks with appeals.
Questions? contact@glp1afterdenial.com
Affiliate Disclosure: Some links earn a small commission at no extra cost to you.

content:
Quick Verdict What Is It Pricing How It Works Pros & Cons Alternatives ‚ö° The Quick Verdict LillyDirect is legit. It's Eli Lilly's official patient access program, and it's the cheapest way to get real, FDA-approved Zepbound without insurance. I used it during my active weight loss phase and had zero issues.
Best For Brand-name quality seekers My Rating ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê 5/5 I spent months on LillyDirect during my weight loss journey. This is my honest review ‚Äî what worked, what didn’t, and who it’s actually right for.
What Is LillyDirect? LillyDirect is Eli Lilly’s direct-to-patient program. It lets you get Zepbound (and other Lilly medications) shipped directly to you at lower prices than you’d pay at a regular pharmacy.
‚úì Key Facts Official program ‚Äî Run by Eli Lilly, the company that makes Zepbound Real medication ‚Äî FDA-approved, pharmaceutical-grade Zepbound No insurance needed ‚Äî Self-pay pricing for everyone HSA/FSA eligible ‚Äî Use pre-tax health savings Requires prescription ‚Äî From your doctor or their telehealth partners Why does this exist? Lilly created LillyDirect because the pharmacy middleman system is broken. List prices are insane ($1,000+/month), and insurance coverage is a mess. LillyDirect cuts out the middlemen.
LillyDirect Pricing (December 2025) Zepbound Monthly Prices Dose Price Notes 2.5mg $299/mo Starter dose (weeks 1-4) 5mg $399/mo First maintenance dose 7.5mg $449/mo Higher dose 10mg $449/mo Higher dose 12.5mg $449/mo Higher dose 15mg $449/mo Maximum dose How This Compares # Source Typical Cost Notes LillyDirect $299-449/mo Self-pay, no insurance Pharmacy (no insurance) $1,000-1,200/mo List price Pharmacy (with insurance) $0-500/mo Highly variable Telehealth compounded $100-250/mo Semaglutide only, not tirzepatide Research peptides $50-150/mo DIY, no prescription Bottom line: LillyDirect is expensive compared to compounded or research peptides, but it’s the cheapest way to get the real thing.
How LillyDirect Works 1 Get a prescription From your doctor, or use one of LillyDirect's telehealth partners (they list options on their site). The prescription needs to specify Zepbound.
2 Create a LillyDirect account Go to lillydirect.lilly.com and sign up. You'll enter your prescription info.
3 Prescription verification LillyDirect confirms your prescription with your doctor. This usually takes 1-3 days.
4 Pay and ship Pay the self-pay price. Medication ships cold-packed to your door, usually within a few days.
5 Monthly refills Set up auto-refills or order manually each month. Dose changes require prescription updates.
What You Receive #Zepbound comes as single-dose auto-injector pens (like an EpiPen). Each box contains 4 pens ‚Äî one month’s supply (one injection per week).
No mixing, no syringes, no math. Just click and inject.
Pros and Cons ‚úì What I Liked Pharmaceutical quality ‚Äî FDA-approved, consistent dosing Pre-filled pens ‚Äî No mixing or calculations Easy ordering ‚Äî Straightforward website and process Fast shipping ‚Äî Usually arrived within 3-5 days HSA/FSA works ‚Äî Used my HSA for all purchases Tirzepatide available ‚Äî Unlike compounded (semaglutide only) ‚úó What I Didn't Like Price ‚Äî $300-450/month adds up fast No vial option ‚Äî Pens only (can't dose flexibly) Prescription hassle ‚Äî Need a doctor willing to prescribe Price jumps at 5mg ‚Äî $100 more per month Long-term cost ‚Äî Unsustainable for indefinite use (for me) My Experience Using LillyDirect I used LillyDirect for about 5 months during my active weight loss phase with Zepbound.
The Good #Ordering was easy. My doctor wrote the prescription, I signed up, and medication arrived within a week. No insurance dance, no prior authorizations, no pharmacy phone calls.
The medication worked. This sounds obvious, but after reading horror stories about sketchy compounded medications, I appreciated knowing I was getting the real thing. Consistent results, consistent side effects (the predictable kind).
HSA made it tolerable. Paying $399-449/month hurt less when it was pre-tax dollars from my HSA. Still expensive, but ~30% easier to swallow.
The Bad #The cost is brutal long-term. At $449/month for my maintenance dose (5mg), I was looking at $5,400/year indefinitely. That’s a vacation. That’s a used car payment. I couldn’t justify it forever.
Dose changes require prescription updates. Every time I titrated up, I needed my doctor to send a new prescription. Minor hassle, but annoying.
Why I Eventually Switched #Once I hit my goal weight, I transitioned to research peptides for maintenance. The cost savings ($50-150/month vs $449/month) made sense for long-term use, and I was comfortable with the DIY aspect after months on the medication.
‚Üí Read my full story
Who Should Use LillyDirect? LillyDirect Is Right For You If: You want FDA-approved, pharmaceutical-grade medication You're new to GLP-1s and want medical oversight You can afford $300-450/month (or have HSA/FSA funds) You specifically want tirzepatide (not semaglutide) You don't want to mix or calculate doses You're in active weight loss mode (not just maintenance) LillyDirect Probably Isn't Right If: Budget is your #1 concern You're comfortable with DIY (research peptides are much cheaper) You want semaglutide ‚Äî compounded is cheaper than brand Wegovy You need flexible dosing (vials let you microdose; pens don't) You're planning to use GLP-1s indefinitely (cost adds up) Alternatives to LillyDirect If LillyDirect’s pricing doesn’t work for you, here are the realistic alternatives:
Telehealth Compounded ($100-250/month) #Platforms like Mochi Health, Hers, and Henry Meds offer compounded semaglutide with a prescription.
Trade-off: Semaglutide only (not tirzepatide). Compounded, not brand. But much cheaper.
‚Üí Compare telehealth platforms
Research Peptides ($50-150/month) #Both semaglutide and tirzepatide available. No prescription needed. You mix and dose yourself.
Trade-off: No FDA oversight, DIY mixing, no medical supervision. But by far the cheapest option, and tirzepatide IS available this way.
‚Üí Reconstitution guide
Comparison Table # Option Monthly Cost Tirzepatide? Prescription? DIY? LillyDirect $299-449 ‚úì Yes Required No Telehealth compounded $100-250 ‚úó No Included No Research peptides $50-150 ‚úì Yes Not needed Yes ‚Üí Full breakdown of all options
Frequently Asked Questions #Is LillyDirect legitimate? Yes. It’s run by Eli Lilly, the pharmaceutical company that manufactures Zepbound. It’s their official patient access program.
Can I use insurance with LillyDirect? LillyDirect is specifically for self-pay. If your insurance covers Zepbound, you’d typically fill through a regular pharmacy (and possibly get a better price with the Zepbound Savings Card).
How long does shipping take? Usually 3-5 business days. Ships cold-packed with ice packs to keep the medication stable.
Can I get a 90-day supply? Currently, LillyDirect offers monthly supplies only.
What if I need to change doses? Your doctor needs to send a new prescription for the new dose. Then you can update your LillyDirect order.
Is there a commitment or subscription? No long-term commitment. You can order month-to-month and stop anytime.
The Bottom Line # LillyDirect is the gold standard for self-pay Zepbound.
If you want real, FDA-approved tirzepatide without dealing with insurance, LillyDirect is the most straightforward option. It's not cheap, but you're getting pharmaceutical-grade medication with zero hassle.
I used it, I'd recommend it for active weight loss, but I switched to cheaper options for long-term maintenance. Your call depends on your budget and comfort level.
Questions? contact@glp1afterdenial.com

What About Insurance? #Most insurance doesn’t cover weight loss medications. But it’s worth checking ‚Äî some plans do cover Zepbound with prior authorization, especially if you have qualifying conditions.

Most telehealth platforms now offer semaglutide only, or can help you access brand-name Zepbound through LillyDirect. How It Works 1Ô∏è‚É£ Sign up 2Ô∏è‚É£ Health questionnaire 3Ô∏è‚É£ Provider review 4Ô∏è‚É£ Prescription 5Ô∏è‚É£ Ships to you Platform Comparison Platform Starting Price Best For Mochi Health ~$99/mo Budget-conscious Hers ~$199/mo Want hand-holding Henry Meds ~$200/mo Clear pricing Ro Varies Want brand-name Mochi Health # ~$99/month ‚Äî Compounded semaglutide Good mobile app, async provider messaging, generally positive reviews.

Best for: People who want a known brand with support included
Watch out: Long-term commitment for best pricing, upselling reported
Henry Meds # ~$200/month ‚Äî Compounded semaglutide Video consultations available, straightforward pricing, good provider communication.
Best for: People who want clear pricing and no surprises

üö© Red Flags to Avoid ‚úó No provider consultation at all ‚Äî You should talk to someone ‚úó Won't name their compounding pharmacy ‚Äî Legit ones will tell you ‚úó Prices way below market ‚Äî $50/month compounded = suspicious ‚úó Claims to offer compounded tirzepatide ‚Äî Legally questionable now ‚úó Pressure to sign long contracts ‚Äî Month-to-month should be an option ‚úó No reviews online ‚Äî Google them first Brand vs Compounded: Does It Matter? üíä Brand (Wegovy, Zepbound) Made by pharma companies FDA-approved Consistent batch to batch Pre-filled pens or vials More expensive üè• Compounded Made by compounding pharmacies Same active ingredient Regulated by state boards Usually in vials Cheaper Does it work the same? For most people, yes. But absorption may vary slightly. If switching from brand to compounded, pay attention to how your body responds.

The LillyDirect Route #If you want brand-name Zepbound specifically:
1 Use a telehealth platform that prescribes brand (like Ro) 2 Ask them to send prescription to LillyDirect 3 Pay LillyDirect's self-pay prices ($299-449/mo) 4 Medication ships to you ‚Üí Full LillyDirect review
My Take #I used Zepbound through LillyDirect during my weight loss phase ‚Äî I wanted pharmaceutical-grade medication while actively losing.
For maintenance, I switched to research peptides because the cost savings matter when you’re on something indefinitely.
Telehealth compounded is a solid middle ground if brand is too expensive and research peptides feel too DIY.

title: Affiliate Disclosure

content:
TLDR 2022: Ozempic 2024: Insurance Zepbound Now: Peptides Lessons üìã The Short Version Lost 40 lbs on Ozempic (2022). Insurance stopped covering it (2024). Weight came back. Tried to get Zepbound covered but insurance didn't cover weight loss and finding doctors to write prior auths was a hassle. Went self-pay with HSA. Now maintaining on research peptides.
2022: Ozempic Changed Everything My doctor prescribed Ozempic and insurance covered it. I didn’t think much about it at the time.
‚ú® What Happened Lost 40 pounds while working out consistently Food noise stopped ‚Äî first time in my life I wasn't constantly thinking about food Inflammation gone ‚Äî stuff I'd dealt with for years disappeared Ozempic (semaglutide) was approved for Type 2 diabetes. The weight loss was technically a “side effect.” This becomes important later.
2024: Insurance Stopped Covering It As GLP-1s got popular for weight loss, insurers got stricter. Many now only cover them for diabetes, not weight management.
‚ùå My Situation Insurance stopped covering Ozempic Prior authorization wasn't even an option with my plan Policy excluded weight loss medications entirely So I stopped taking it. Figured I’d maintain with diet and exercise.
I was wrong. The weight came back. The food noise returned.
Late 2024: Zepbound (Self-Pay) After gaining the weight back, I knew I needed to get back on medication. I looked into getting Zepbound covered by insurance.
‚ö° The Reality My insurance didn't cover Zepbound for weight loss Finding doctors willing to write prior authorizations was a hassle I knew it was going to be an uphill battle So I skipped the headache. My doctor prescribed Zepbound for weight loss and I went straight to self-pay using my HSA. LillyDirect made it available at lower prices than the crazy list price.
‚Üí Full guide: How to get Zepbound covered (or what to do if you can’t)
Zepbound vs Ozempic ‚Äî My Experience Ozempic Zepbound Active ingredient Semaglutide Tirzepatide How it works 1 hormone (GLP-1) 2 hormones (GLP-1 + GIP) Strength Effective Stronger Side effects Manageable More intense at first My results Lost 40 lbs over months Lost regained weight in 4-5 months I worked up to 5mg ‚Äî that was my sweet spot.
‚Üí Full LillyDirect review
Now: Maintenance on Research Peptides Once I hit my goal weight, I had options:
Stay on Zepbound at $449+/month forever Try to maintain without meds (already failed at this) Research peptides for maintenance I chose research peptides ‚Äî lower dose, much cheaper ($50-150/month).
‚ö†Ô∏è This Isn't For Everyone Knowing how to reconstitute (mix the powder) Calculating your own doses No medical oversight Comfort with the legal gray area But I’d already been on both medications, knew how my body responded, and only needed a low maintenance dose. It’s working for me.
‚Üí How to reconstitute peptides ¬∑ ‚Üí Dosing calculator
What I Wish I'd Known üö® Protein and Hair Loss Many people lose hair on GLP-1s. It's usually preventable.
When you eat way less (which these meds cause), you might not get enough protein, water, or vitamins. Hair loss is often the first sign you're undereating protein. Aim for 100+ grams/day.
The Insurance Maze Medication Approved For Insurance Reality Ozempic Diabetes Usually covered with diabetes diagnosis Wegovy Weight loss Rarely covered, requires prior auth Mounjaro Diabetes Usually covered with diabetes diagnosis Zepbound Weight loss Sometimes covered with qualifying conditions Qualifying conditions that can help: PCOS, sleep apnea (Zepbound is specifically approved for this), cardiovascular disease, NAFLD, hypertension, prediabetes.
But be warned ‚Äî finding doctors willing to write prior authorizations can be a hassle, and even then your plan might just not cover it. I eventually decided self-pay was less stressful.
‚Üí Full insurance coverage guide
üí∞ LillyDirect Pricing (Late 2025) 2.5mg: $299/month 5mg: $399/month Higher doses: $449/month Not cheap, but way less than the $1,000+ list price. HSA makes it pre-tax.
‚Üí Full LillyDirect review
Where I Am Now ‚úÖ At goal weight üíä Low-dose peptides üèãÔ∏è Consistent exercise ü•© High protein Is this the “right” approach? I don’t know. It’s what’s working for me.
What's Next? Compare Options Full breakdown Telehealth Which are legit Reconstitution How to mix Questions? contact@glp1afterdenial.com

content:
Disclaimer: This is for educational purposes. Research peptides are not FDA-approved for human use. I’m not a medical professional ‚Äî just sharing what I learned.
What You’ll Need #From the Peptide Supplier #I use Royal Peptides ‚Äî they have both semaglutide (Ozempic/Wegovy) and tirzepatide (Mounjaro/Zepbound).
Lyophilized (freeze-dried) semaglutide or tirzepatide vial Supplies to Buy # Item Purpose Link Bacteriostatic water Mixes with peptide Amazon Insulin syringes (29-31g) Drawing & injecting Amazon Alcohol swabs Sterilizing Amazon Sharps container Safe disposal Amazon ‚ö†Ô∏è Use bacteriostatic water, NOT sterile water. BAC water has a preservative that prevents bacteria growth. Sterile water doesn’t ‚Äî use within 24 hours only.
The Math # Don’t want to do math? Use the Dosing Calculator
The Formula #Step 1: Calculate concentration
peptide (mg) √∑ water (mL) = mg per mL Step 2: Calculate units to draw
desired dose (mg) √∑ concentration (mg/mL) √ó 100 = units Example # 5mg vial + 2mL water = 2.5 mg/mL Want 0.5mg dose? 0.5 √∑ 2.5 √ó 100 = 20 units Quick Reference Charts #Semaglutide 5mg + 2mL Water (2.5 mg/mL) # Dose Draw This 0.25mg 10 units 0.5mg 20 units 1.0mg 40 units 1.7mg 68 units 2.4mg 96 units Tirzepatide 10mg + 2mL Water (5 mg/mL) # Dose Draw This 2.5mg 50 units 5.0mg 100 units 7.5mg 150 units 10mg 200 units Step-by-Step Reconstitution # Step 1: Prep # Wash hands thoroughly Wipe both vial tops with alcohol swabs Let dry 10-15 seconds Step 2: Draw Water # Pull back syringe plunger to desired amount Insert needle into BAC water vial Push air in, draw water out Tap out air bubbles Step 3: Add Water to Peptide #‚ö†Ô∏è IMPORTANT: Aim needle at the glass wall, not directly at the powder. Let water run down the side slowly.
Step 4: Mix Gently #DO NOT SHAKE. Shaking damages the peptide.
Swirl gently in circles, OR Just let it sit 5-15 minutes ‚Äî it dissolves on its own Solution should be clear. If cloudy or has particles, don’t use.
Step 5: Label & Store # Write date and concentration on vial Refrigerate (not freezer) Good for 4-6 weeks Injection Technique #Where to Inject # Abdomen
2+ inches from belly button Front of Thighs
Middle, outer area Back of Upper Arms
Fatty area How to Inject # Clean site with alcohol swab, let dry Pinch skin to create a fold Insert needle at 45-90¬∞ angle Release pinch Push plunger slowly Wait 5-10 seconds before removing Don’t rub the site Rotate sites ‚Äî don’t use the same spot twice in a row.
Dosing Schedules #Semaglutide (Typical Titration) # Weeks Dose Frequency 1-4 0.25mg Once weekly 5-8 0.5mg Once weekly 9-12 1.0mg Once weekly 13-16 1.7mg Once weekly 17+ 2.4mg Once weekly Tirzepatide (Typical Titration) # Weeks Dose Frequency 1-4 2.5mg Once weekly 5-8 5.0mg Once weekly 9-12 7.5mg Once weekly 13+ 10-15mg Once weekly üí° Tip: Go slower if side effects are rough. Many people maintain at lower doses than the max.
Common Mistakes # ‚ùå Using sterile water instead of BAC water
‚ùå Shaking the vial (swirl gently instead)
‚ùå Shooting water directly at powder
‚ùå Storing at room temperature after mixing
‚ùå Freezing reconstituted peptide
‚ùå Reusing needles
‚ùå Starting dose too high
Storage # State Where How Long Powder (unmixed) Fridge or freezer Months Reconstituted Fridge only 4-6 weeks Never freeze reconstituted peptide or leave it at room temp.
Side Effects #Common (especially when starting):
Nausea (worst first 1-2 days after injection) Decreased appetite Constipation or diarrhea Fatigue Managing them:
Start low, increase slowly Stay hydrated Eat protein even when not hungry Some people inject at night to sleep through nausea When to Get Help üö® # Seek medical attention for:
Severe, persistent abdominal pain Signs of thyroid issues (neck lump, trouble swallowing) Severe allergic reaction Signs of severe dehydration Questions? # Reach out at contact@glp1afterdenial.com

This is especially important if you have:
Diabetes or blood sugar issues Thyroid problems or family history of thyroid cancer Kidney or liver disease History of pancreatitis Any other medical conditions Research Peptides #The information about research peptides on this site is educational. Research peptides are:

You are responsible for your own health decisions You will consult healthcare professionals as needed You won’t hold me liable for any health outcomes You understand this is personal experience, not medical advice Emergency #If you experience severe side effects or a medical emergency, seek immediate medical attention. Don’t rely on information from a blog.

  • Encouragement to use any medication without medical supervision

Talk to a Doctor #

Before starting, stopping, or changing any medication ‚Äî including GLP-1 agonists ‚Äî consult with a qualified healthcare provider.
title: Medical Disclaimer

content:
Last updated: December 2024
The Short Version #I don’t collect much data. This is a personal blog, not a data company. Here’s what happens when you visit:
What I Collect #Automatically (via hosting):
Basic analytics (page views, general location by country) Standard server logs (IP addresses, browser type) If you email me:
Your email address and message content That’s it. No accounts, no tracking cookies, no selling your data.
Third-Party Services #Netlify (hosting): Handles basic server functions. See their privacy policy.
Amazon Associates: If you click an Amazon affiliate link, Amazon handles that transaction and their privacy policy applies.
Other affiliate programs: Similar deal ‚Äî once you click to a partner site, their privacy policy applies.
Cookies #This site uses minimal cookies:
Essential cookies for site functionality No advertising cookies No cross-site tracking Your Rights #You can:
Email me to ask what data I have about you (probably nothing) Ask me to delete any data I have Opt out of any emails (just reply and ask) Contact #Questions about privacy? Email me at contact@glp1afterdenial.com
Changes #I’ll update this page if anything changes. No sneaky stuff.

title: Privacy Policy

content:
Use this calculator to figure out your concentration after reconstitution and how many units to draw for your dose.
Step 1: Reconstitution Peptide amount in vial (mg) Common: 5mg or 10mg vials BAC water to add (mL) Common: 1mL or 2mL Your Concentration: 2.5 mg/mL Step 2: Calculate Your Dose Desired dose (mg) Draw this much: 10 units (0.1 mL) Quick Reference Tables #Semaglutide 5mg Vial + 2mL BAC Water (2.5 mg/mL) # Dose Units to Draw Volume 0.25mg 10 units 0.10 mL 0.5mg 20 units 0.20 mL 1.0mg 40 units 0.40 mL 1.7mg 68 units 0.68 mL 2.0mg 80 units 0.80 mL 2.4mg 96 units 0.96 mL Semaglutide 5mg Vial + 1mL BAC Water (5 mg/mL) # Dose Units to Draw Volume 0.25mg 5 units 0.05 mL 0.5mg 10 units 0.10 mL 1.0mg 20 units 0.20 mL 1.7mg 34 units 0.34 mL 2.0mg 40 units 0.40 mL 2.4mg 48 units 0.48 mL Tirzepatide 10mg Vial + 2mL BAC Water (5 mg/mL) # Dose Units to Draw Volume 2.5mg 50 units 0.50 mL 5.0mg 100 units 1.00 mL 7.5mg 150 units 1.50 mL 10mg 200 units 2.00 mL Note: For doses above 100 units, you may need a larger syringe or split into two injections.
Tirzepatide 10mg Vial + 1mL BAC Water (10 mg/mL) # Dose Units to Draw Volume 2.5mg 25 units 0.25 mL 5.0mg 50 units 0.50 mL 7.5mg 75 units 0.75 mL 10mg 100 units 1.00 mL 12.5mg 125 units 1.25 mL 15mg 150 units 1.50 mL The Formula #It’s simple math once you understand it:
Concentration: peptide (mg) √∑ water (mL) = mg per mL
Units to draw: desired dose (mg) √∑ concentration (mg/mL) √ó 100 = units
Example # You have a 5mg vial of semaglutide You add 2mL of BAC water Concentration: 5 √∑ 2 = 2.5 mg/mL You want 0.5mg dose Units: 0.5 √∑ 2.5 √ó 100 = 20 units Tips # Less water = more concentrated (smaller injection volume, but harder to measure small doses accurately) More water = less concentrated (easier to measure, but larger injection volume) 2mL is a good middle ground for most people Always double-check your math before injecting Start with lower doses if you’re new to these medications Supplies You’ll Need # Bacteriostatic water Insulin syringes (29-31 gauge) Alcohol swabs Sharps container ‚Üê Back to Reconstitution Guide
Affiliate Disclosure: Some links on this site are affiliate links. If you purchase through them, I may earn a small commission at no extra cost to you. I only recommend products I’ve personally used or thoroughly researched.
section: GLP-1 Guides: Dosing, Reconstitution, Supplies & More
summary:
Use this calculator to figure out your concentration after reconstitution and how many units to draw for your dose.

Step 1: Reconstitution

Common: 5mg or 10mg vials
Common: 1mL or 2mL
Your Concentration:
2.5 mg/mL

Step 2: Calculate Your Dose

Draw this much:
10 units
(0.1 mL)

Quick Reference Tables #

Semaglutide 5mg Vial + 2mL BAC Water (2.5 mg/mL) #

Dose Units to Draw Volume
0.25mg 10 units 0.10 mL
0.5mg 20 units 0.20 mL
1.0mg 40 units 0.40 mL
1.7mg 68 units 0.68 mL
2.0mg 80 units 0.80 mL
2.4mg 96 units 0.96 mL

Semaglutide 5mg Vial + 1mL BAC Water (5 mg/mL) #

Dose Units to Draw Volume
0.25mg 5 units 0.05 mL
0.5mg 10 units 0.10 mL
1.0mg 20 units 0.20 mL
1.7mg 34 units 0.34 mL
2.0mg 40 units 0.40 mL
2.4mg 48 units 0.48 mL

Tirzepatide 10mg Vial + 2mL BAC Water (5 mg/mL) #

Dose Units to Draw Volume
2.5mg 50 units 0.50 mL
5.0mg 100 units 1.00 mL
7.5mg 150 units 1.50 mL
10mg 200 units 2.00 mL

Note: For doses above 100 units, you may need a larger syringe or split into two injections.
title: Semaglutide & Tirzepatide Dosing Calculator: Units to Draw
